reasoning: The critique targets a real supporting move in the essay—its “random walk” intuition for why reflection increases divergence, and the associated downplaying of convergence mechanisms under antirealism. If successful, this would moderately weaken the paper’s pessimism about WAM-convergence (and strengthen the ‘trade/constitution’ route), but it wouldn’t overturn the essay’s broader case because multiple independent arguments remain (metaethical alienness/motivation, lock-in/blockers, threats, concentration of power). The critique’s argument is plausible but underdeveloped: it asserts that shared empirical/strategic constraints and bargaining equilibria can produce convergence, but doesn’t show they yield (i) convergence on the good de dicto (motivation), (ii) convergence fine-grained enough to hit the paper’s “narrow target,” or (iii) convergence to anything ‘accurate’ rather than merely stable/legible/legitimate. Most claims are reasonable as possibilities, though somewhat overstated (coordination pressures can also entrench local optima or superficial conformity, as the essay notes). The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and has little extraneous material.
title: Moral Reflection Follows Shared Constraints, Not Random Walk
